142407778.review:
In the realm of gaming, where a thirst for captivating titles is insatiable, this game immediately stands out as a refreshing choice. This unique and enjoyable experience is worth sharing, as it successfully piques interest and offers a delightful adventure.

From the moment you dive into the gameplay, it's impossible not to be captivated by the enchanting visuals that radiate an undeniable aura of adorableness. The masterful developers have woven a tapestry of visual delight, and the endearing pug protagonists only serve to enhance the game's enchantment.

The gameplay, featuring procedurally generated levels and weather elements, injects a degree of unpredictability into each run. This ensures that no two playthroughs feel exactly the same, maintaining a high level of engagement throughout.

One standout aspect is the system for unlocking new costumes and characters. Each unlock comes with its own set of moves, effectively creating a doggy wardrobe with unique abilities. This feature adds an enjoyable layer of motivation for players to explore further and experiment with different combinations.

In terms of difficulty, Turbo Pug strikes a fine balance catering to a wide range of players. It avoids being overly challenging, making it accessible to casual gamers, while still offering enough obstacles to keep it from feeling too easy. This middle ground is appreciated, allowing players to enjoy the game without becoming overly frustrated.

However, one area where the game could improve is in adding more elements of distraction during races. While the graphics and adorable pug characters are endearing, a bit more gameplay variety could enhance the overall experience.

In sum, Turbo Pug delivers a charming and visually delightful adventure. The graphics and unlockable costumes add an enjoyable layer to the gameplay, and the balance of difficulty makes it accessible to a broad audience. While it might lack some deeper gameplay elements, it still manages to provide a pleasant and enjoyable gaming experience for those seeking a lighthearted escapade.

Left mouse-click or hit space bar to make Turbo Pug jump. Avoid hazards, pits, and lighting. That's it!

Leaves a "one more go" feeling to try and best your score. 

The random "only lucky to avoid" lighting strikes are cheap and can ruin a good run. 

Still a good purchase though.

140633555.review: Turbo Pug is an infinitely scrolling platformer where you play as a pug and aim to reach a score as high as possible. That’s pretty much all there is to this game, think of it as a slightly upgraded, pug-themed version of the dinosaur game from Google Chrome. There are a few characters to unlock and I guess getting occasionally zapped by lightning is a funny addition. In regards to gameplay, free mobile games like Subway Surfers are probably better and more convenient alternatives but if you have a particular fascination with pugs you might enjoy this game more. Usually I wouldn’t recommend paying money for a game this simple with free alternatives but since it is remarkably cheap and doesn’t pretend to be anything more than it is I’ll give it a positive review of 5/10.

Pensaba que más adelante tendría algunas habilidades más, como una propulsión especial o algo, pero no lo he visto todavía.

Respecto a la dificultad, para mí es bastante difícil, ya que en ningún momento puedes detener al perro, solo se puede saltar. Las pantallas cambian, pero si no las pasas, al final se repiten una y otra vez, con lo cual me está empezando a aburrir. 
Los personajes puedes cambiarlos, y sus habilidades de salto y velocidad varían. En conclusión, es un juego para matar el rato y entretenerte.

This game is the pinnacle of modern civilization and should be experienced by only those deserving of enlightenment. Many ask me what I do on my free time and I always retort with the simple: "thinking about [i]Turbo Pug[/i]" and it never fails to maintain my questioner silent, I assume it is because they are also thinking of [i]Turbo Pug[/i]. If I could sell my internal organs in exchange for every person in the world getting access to this masterpiece, I surely would. Contents[show]
History
Dogwelder was a member of Section Eight. During the reformation of the team Dogwelder was trapping and killing dogs in alleyways. He helped fight the Mawzir's henchmen during Hitman:Smoking Aces.[1][2][3] In Hitman: Super Guy Dogwelder and Section Eight fought The Many Angled Ones. He was vaporized and killed by The Many Angled Ones.[4]

He was succeeded by Dogwelder II.

[h1]Here is my amazing review of the game Turbo Pug by Back To Basics Games.[/h1]
It has some charming 8 bit graphics and is what you would expect from an excellent developer of platformer games like this masterpiece. There are different pugs like the the rainbow "LGBT rights" pug or the Sombrero "Don't build the wall" pug. There are also cats too, but if you need to use them for their advantages you might as well just play as the lgbt pug anyways. There is also a pug point system used to unlock all the charcters with a certain amount of points that you obtain by running and picking up spinning pug heads. The game has no difficulty settings, so if you are bad then please consult a doctor. I recommend muting the soundtrack because its the same 3 notes over and over again so just play darude sandstorm instead. If you are a normie then learn your doggo terminology before play this game. When you are about to beat your highscore you will always die 1 point off, no matter what.
[b]Overall rating: yes

31219049.review:
This is an endless runner/platformer with a 2D retro pixel style and a pug themed gimmick.

Level design is simplistic and doesn't really make much sense, lava and flying rocks and blades and things, I guess they aren't trying to tell any story here, just sell on the pixel pug schtick. 

Performance is good and smooth in 4K with no overscan/DPI issues, mostly due to Unity, allowing baristas to pretend to be game developers since 2005.  

Controls are clunky and unforgiving yet also frustratingly unresponsive for a twitch reflex game.

Art is extremely poor, being retro/pixel styled, and limited to 2D.

Control issues combined with general low effort game design and no depth beyond "gimmicks" make this difficult to recommend.

30464407.review:
I walked into Turbo Pug expecting a sub-par, poor excuse for a game.
I was dead wrong.
Turbo Pug as a game is fantastic, but as an EXPERIENCE it shines brighter than any star in the sky. You play the role of a pug journeying to collect "pug points". The simplicity of Turbo Pug's mechanics is a breath of fresh air in the midst of all the unnecessarily complex action games found in the market today. Graphically, Turbo Pug is not only pleasing to the eye, but the very soul. You'll become attached to the protagonist pug, as well as the multitude of other pugs (and other secret animals) you can take control of, not only for their well-defined proportions and realistic appearance, but for the absolutely perfect way their character is portrayed. The soundtrack is miles above the video game "standard". The two songs that feature in the game have a unique timelessness to them that'll have you bopping your head for days after playing.
All in all, Turbo Pug is THE game of this generation. 10/10, will have me playing for years and years to come.

Overal waste of money.

25658282.review:
My steam counter says I've played this game for 4 hours. It's actually probably been over 20 total. Sometimes it stops counting for some reason.

This super simple, barebones, yet adorable little game is well worth your 99 cents. 

It's in the style of games like Geometry Dash and Impossible Game in that you have a little character (pug) that continuously runs to the right, and you have to jump over and onto stuff while avoiding obstacles.

I figured I'd enjoy it for a half hour or so and be done with it, as it's super basic. Only two music tracks that quickly get lose their mild pleasantness after hearing them for the 12th time. Repetitive obstacle sets which repeat themselves often mixed in with occasional randomized infuriating difficulty spikes.

But somehow it all works. I found myself playing this for an hour at a time just to get a [i]slightly[/i] higher score.

Plus it has a nice selection of alt-pugs with slightly different characteristics (one double jumps, another is floaty etc.), along with a pinguin. The pinguin is just obviously a sad joke from the developers. He's super slow and cannot even clear his first jump. :(

Pick this up instead of a candy bar. It's deceptively engaging and adorable.

25167944.review: Turbo pug is a simple, cheap and enjoyable endless runner game. I was drawn in by the design and when I saw it on sale at half price I couldn't resist. I like the concept behind the game and the art style is well done but I do have a few things I am less fond of. For me, the main problem with the game is that there is little motivation to actually play. I'm not asking for an deep storyline or anything but I think the game would be better if it actually challenged and rewarded its players. I found it upsetting that there were all these unique unlockable characters but there is no information on what you need to do to unlock them. You aren't notified when you unlock a new character and it feels like you didn't really accomplish anything to deserve them. The 'pug points' also feel useless and it would be neat if a feature was added where you could use them to buy powerups of some sort to advance further in the game. The world design is a bit bland and repetitive so traveling further doesn't really add to the experience. In my opinon these changes could make the game go from mediorce to fun and addictive. This game isn't for everyone but I would reccomend it to anyone who is a fan of pugs and wants a game to play a few short rounds of in their spare time.

24988054.review:
TL:DR It is a nice, cheap game but if you want quality your better off waiting for a similar game to go on sale.

What is the game?
In this game you start off as a Pug and then you are placed into an endless runner, not to much more to say.

World Design?
This is my main problem with the game, I wouldn't say the world design is that good.
First off in your first run you have probably seen most of it and second of all it is inconsistant.
There are some parts where it's really easy but then you have parts that require exact timing unless you have double jump, even then sometimes you can't double jump over it because behind the obsticle if you double jump you'll fall off of the map.
This would be fine but there is no progression, it seems to go on until you lose, lets take Subway Surfers, it gets faster and faster the higher score you get, this might be in Turbo Pug but it isn't really visible and only having to tap space doesn't give the same thrills.
Also it is just kinda bland, yes there are big spikes but it isn't fun to dodge, it's sort of like an army sending one man at a time against you, it is good to get used to it but eventually it's just doing the same thing over and over until one gets lucky, it would be much more fun to send two men at me, then three ect, it would also solve the problem of progression.

Unlocks.
I don't really know what to say about the unlocks, the cosmetic changes are nice but I feel like they should seperate cosmetic changes and actual game changes.
For example I think the pug in a mexican hat looks cute so I go to play him, however he feels way to light so I can't play as him, if they just seperated it then you could have comfortable controls and your favourite cosmetic animal.
That also brings me to another point, some unlocks just feel off, the mexican pug feels way to light, the frozen pug feels to heavy, the penguin is unplayable, even my favourite (pumpkin pug) feels a tad bit to heavy.
Also it isn't clear how to unlock them, I think it's getting to a point where you see red vases but the game never tells me, it also doesn't tell me when I unlock something.
However I do like how the added other animals if you don't like pugs but when it's a game called Turbo Pug it doesn't really make sense for non-pug fans to play.

Graphics
I don't have much to say about the graphics except that the art style is quite nice.

Controls
The space bar is to jump, probably the best button to jump, you can't do anything else.
I wouldn't say this is a controls issue however it's related, why can't I press space to replay? Where is the logic? If I am playing an endless runner with one button atleast let me used it to start a new game instead of having to use my mouse, it's just annoying.

Music
The music is nice and happy, I would rather play other music as with an endless runner your not doing much so listening to music or a podcast would make it more entertaining but the music's alright...
But come on I don't want to listen to the same one or two songs over and over and over again.

Conclusion
This isn't really a "game" game more just a time killer, so as much as I think it's wrong to review it as a "game", it runs around screaming "I am a game" so I will treat it as such, I would give it a 2/10.
So why recomend it? Well as much as it is said I would have liked a neutral/depends button because you know you arn't going for a rich gaming expirence but for the price of £0.79 (often on sale for £0.39) it can kill a few hours which a movie demands £5 for.
But if you like pugs why not pick it up when you have spare money on your steam account?
-ShadowGamerPug

Guau!
Estamos ante un juego electrónico en el que una o más personas interactúan, por medio de un controlador, con un dispositivo dotado de imágenes de vídeo. Es un plataformas complejo, placentoro, violento, tenso, lleno de acción y con momentos con mucho miedo. Esta hecho de una forma para que te identifiques con el personaje principal de esta compleja trama (un perro), sientes que eres tu el perro: tu ladras, tu corres, tu perreas hasta que para de llover, tu sientes ese gran sentimiento que te invita a córrer como un animal, etcétera. Tiene una gran e innovadora jugabilidad (utilizas un botón para saltar y... ya) y una gran historia. Lo que de verdad te emosiona de este apasionante título es la metáfora que lleva en su interior: El perro es en realidad un gato que huye de un elefante porque el gato le ha arañado la trompa enorme al hijo del elefante, Pedro Sindulfo.

23790380.review:
Turbo Pug es un juego bien conocido por su elevada dificultad. Aún con esas, muchos jugadores se aventuran a empezar una partida en este reconocido título de Pug Life debido a las numerosas recomendaciones que reciben por foros y vídeos de la cominudad. De hecho uno de los puntos fuertes del juego es la comunidad que tiene detrás , creando contenido fan, jugando y divirtiéndose día tras día.

En cuanto al juego en sí mismo, puede definirse como obra maestra, la más alta aspiración que puede tener un RPG. Una ambientación inigualable y una historia INCREIBLE, que si bién no entiendes la primera vez que juegas por la forma en la que es contada, empiezas a descubrir poco a poco indagando en Internet y rejugando una y otra vez el juego. La jugabilidad no es descriptible con otra palabra que "perfecta": El combate, una vez que dominas los controles (recomiendo personalmente un mando, o en el peor de los casos utilizar alguno de los mods existentes para mejorar el teclado/ratón) ofrece muchísimas posibilidades y estilos de juego para complacer a cualquiera. Otro aspecto favorable de la jugabilidad son las cinemáticas: Épicas y solo usadas para narrar lo necesario, siendo muy importante la historia narrada en el propio gameplay. En cuanto a duración, la primera vez dura aproximadamente entre 40 y 60 horas, pero la alta rejugabilidad, sumada al juego online y a los desafiantes logros por desbloquear, hacen que si te gusta puedas dedicarle más de 200 horas y seguir con la misma ilusión por continuar.

Pero vamos con el que es, sin duda, el aspecto más fuerte de Turbo Pug: La dificultad. Es innegable que Turbo Pug es un juego bastante más dificil que la media de juegos actuales. Pero hay algo que todo el mundo debe conocer, y es que es una dificultad sana. Me explico: Quiero decir que sí, obviamente la primera vez que juegas te parecerá un infierno, morirás una y otra vez en cada zona del juego si excepción. Avanzar será una tarea agonizante de prueba y error en las primeras horas de juego. Y recalco: en las primeras horas de juego. Una vez que vayas adquiriendo experiencia de juego, vayas aprendiendo las mecánicas y empieces a entender cómo funcionan las cosas en este "mundillo", cada vez será más fácil avanzar (por no hablar de diversos estilos de juego que puedes adoptar y facilitan la tarea). Pero si hay otro adjetivo que defina a Turbo Pug aparte de difícil, éste es gratificante. Saltar un pincho tras lo que en ese momento te parecen miles y miles de intentos te da una sensación enorme de realización y superación que muy pocas veces sientes con otros juegos. Abreviando, la dificultad sí es elevada, pero no es nada que un jugador medio no pueda superar con algo de esmero y tiempo, y que además será recompensada con una gran satisfacción.

Por supuesto que Turbo Pug tiene algunos defectos como son el a veces desesperante rendimiento de la versión para PC aún sin ser sus gráficos nada del otro mundo, o la poca actividad online que tiene actualmente debido a la antigüedad y la salida de sus sucesores Super Neo Mega Pug y Space Pug, pero son aspectos tan aislados que se ven completamente eclipsados por la radiante perfección del juego en su conjunto.

Para resumir, Turbo Pug es sin duda una experiencia que ningún jugador debe pasar por alto, siendo un juego que te asegura un reto y te recompensará con una gran ambientación, historia, y por supuesto horas y horas de diversión.

23770128.review: Turbo Pug....how does one describe such a beauty in words? From the charming, relatable pugs & other animals found in Turbo Pug, to the inspiring virtual barks littered throughout the game's gorgeous soundtrack, Turbo Pug attempts what no game has done before, and vastly succeeds. A true revolution in the gaming industry, Turbo Pug not only offers a sense of realism, as the impeccable storytelling of the pug's life, including his mental and physical struggles (i.e. lightning) and his complex love life with Space Kitty offer a narrative never before seen. The game, or, masterpiece, also offers a style of gameplay entirely new to the industry, shaking up the game and acting as a message for triple A developers to step it up. There is a common question asked when dealing with video games... "are video games considered art?" Turbo Pug puts an end to this debate, silencing the haters, as there is no doubt in anyone's mind that this game is on par with the Mona Lisa. Turbo Pug deserves a standing ovation, in all honesty. I love Turbo Pig.

One day I saw a game on the steam market, it was on sale and it had a cute pug on its cover. Being myself, a pug loving weeb, I clicked as fast as I could on the colorful fenomena of a game. No, I didnt even bother watching the trailer because who does that these days, right?

 After seeing the unbearable price, I called my economical manager to sort things out. We fought for hours and hours on end until I finally managed to get the money I needed. It had taken many loans but as said love for pugs blocked my self consciousness, no questions were ever made from my side. I downloaded the game in a hurry and then played it with joy, stearing into the eyes of the helpless little pug. The pug was life, the pug was love. No one had ever given me such love and compassion as the pug did, no one, ever. Even though the pug showed love, it also brought me evil. I started hearing the pugs little bark on random equations through out my day, and after getting several mental breakdowns on my work place, the beloved friend and boss of mine had had enough. 

My love for pugs had let me down, leaving me starving on a urine stained street corner in the middle of NYC. My debts were skyhigh as my of my recent pug related loans, my economical manager had also left me, in shame that is. Now I stand here on weak legs with nothing but regrets, writing this review from a strangers macbook at a local 7eleven in hopes of no one falling in the same narrow path as I once did. Please take my word. Love - Halallaren.

22293070.review:
We now know why pugs have such flat faces.

Turbo pug is a frustratingly pure  platformer; you have a jump button, that's it. The game is responsive, fair and quick to get into. That said, expect to die over and over. 

The game has three noteworthy flaws: 

- There should be a keyboard button to restart; preferably the same button you use to jump. As it stands, I find myself leaving my cursor in the middle of the screen just to be able to hit restart qicker. 

- Occational lightningstrikes will temporarily remove your control over the character: this seems unreasonable for an otherwise very fair game.

-Dark spikes and frequent dark backgrounds dont blend well.

That said, the game is a good laugh and  a decent time killer. I wouldn't recommend playing for more than a few minutes at a time, but I certainly would recommend those few minutes. It is a simple game, with a simple mechanic, fused with functional procedurally generated levels and some devilishly cute pixel art.

21515735.review:
I missed the sale on this, so when I became aware of the game, I purchased it. Judging by the tags which included Indie, 2D, Casual, and Difficult, I thought it was a platformer. It certainly looked that way to me at first glance, but I was wrong. This is actually an endless runner game with platforming elements, including obstacles.

Right off the bat, I had a little trouble with the game, because the full-screen option didn't work for me. When at full screen, I saw that the top half of the screen was black, and the bottom half was cut off after the play game option. I had no recourse but to play in windowed mode which created or exacerbated graphical issues.

The next hurdle I came up against was the lack of controller support. To be fair, the game is not advertised as having full or even partial controller support, but it's been my experience that a lot of games have inherent controller support, or partial support, even when that functionality is not disclosed or advertised. Now, armed with the knowledge that this was an endless runner without controller support, I launched JoyToKey, which afforded me partial controller functionality. I still had to use the mouse to click play, and there was no reliable way to exit the game except for using alt+tab to simply close the open window, but at least I could finally play the game.

Graphically, I had difficulty seeing a lot of the obstacles. The day/night cycles and weather element add depth to the game but made visual distinction even more difficult. As the screen got darker, or more muddled, I could reliably see less and less on this tiny windowed screen. This is not something you want to experience in a game like this where the screen is side-scrolling quickly, and you have little reaction time.

In regard to game mechanics, there's some solid work here. Once I began to utilize JoyToKey to enable partial controller support, I could tell that the controls were consistent and responsive. If a little more care was put into graphical considerations, I wouldn't have any difficulty playing this game, and it would still be a challenge.

There's no story or purpose to this game, other than challenging yourself to get a little further than you did before, so if that's what you're after, it's best to look elsewhere. There are also no achievements. This is simply a time-killer, a casual game that can be played in short spurts. Not every game has to be a "thinker," so I'm perfectly okay with that, and that fact did not diminish my rating. 

In regard to level design, there wasn't anything that thrilled or impressed me, but there wasn't anything that I necessarily hated, either. There's definitely some repetition, and memory certainly plays as much if not more of a factor than skill when it comes to being successful at playing this game. While it's not something I'm likely to revisit, I can certainly appreciate it for what it is.

Overall, I can recommend the game to those looking for a casual game that can be played for short periods of time and without becoming completely consuming or engrossing. I can also recommend it to folks looking for an endless runner and those who like platformers but would be willing to try an endless runner that includes platforming elements.

20714742.review:
Turbo Pug is a 2D, one dimensional forever runner that has you jumping over pits and spikes across a single level. You keep running forward until you fall into a pit or hit an object. This is a game that lives and dies by how addictive you are to clicking your mouse and its cheap one dollar price tag. After about five minutes in, I felt like I had seen everything. At fifteen minutes I had unlocked the twelve playable characters. Its worth a dollar, but if you're looking for something deeper than a mobile game on your computer, then look elsewhere.

The game does have a few things going for it: graphics and charm. The charm of a goofy little pug and unlockable chocolate pugs, rainbow pugs, cats, space cats and Santa hats adds a lot to a baron and starved game. The graphics have a great style and it fits that retro style. To make things more interesting, the day and night will cycle, and you'll see rain or snow happen. Its all random so it feels like the single level is dynamic and changing.

This single level throws patterns at you. One pattern has ramps and two boxes, another has two pits, there's one with a large pit and two floating boxes. Later patterns start having giant spikes and saw blades. The saw blades are dark, so seeing them at night becomes an issue. I will guess there are a mere ten or so patterns.

The control is simple; mouse click or use the space bar to jump. The space bar is less strain on your wrist, but then if you fail, you still need to use the mouse anyway to click play again. It would just be nice to have a keyboard work the menu, but why do that when you can throw a game out the door and make money? There is no support for controllers, which is never an issue, but with a game as sparse as this, its tough to think of anything to say to fluff out a review.

Every frame that you stay alive, you get a point. Then there are pug pellets for lack of a better term where then you get either fifty or one hundred points. Oh my! Puggles getting pellets getting points. Yes you is. Who's a good pug wagging his tongue while he runs? You is!

With each failure, you see your points, your high score and your overall accumulation of points. I assume the overall points unlock pugs, because the game never told me I had unlocked anything. To the game's credit, each of the playable animals does feel just a bit different. It seems like the lunar kitty has less gravity and other animals seem to run faster. Without a description of how they're different, you just need to play. I prefer the default two pugs that the game comes with to any that get unlocked.

To keep you in the game there's a leader board, but that's it. The game could have had more leader board integration such as challenge your friends or even online multiplayer where you compete on the same course. When someone loses you keep going and they drop out.

As I ran, I noticed a few glitches here and there. Nothing game breaking, but sometimes the hill terrain has a line. I've also noticed seems between the background where the background loops.

Turbo Pug is a game that kept me occupied for a good ten minutes. There are better games out there that do the same thing, but Turbo Pug just looks better and has a better flavor than other forever runners. Its too simple to be played on anything but a phone when you're waiting for something else, but hey its still fun.

20678914.review:
This is a very simple, one button game.  Time your jumps.  Don't fall.  Don't touch bad.  Remember Robot Unicorn Attack?  It's kinda like that without the whimsy of customization.  Not a bad game.  It's very cute, for what it is.

Redeeming Qualities:
+PUGS!  AHMUHGOD!  DA' PUGZZZZ!
+A nice handful of unlockable characters that have different abilities.  
+Straight-forward gameplay.  Anyone can pick this up and play it.  Only the best button spammers (and hackers) shall master it.
+Absolutely adorable design.
+Also, penguins.
+Surprisingly addictive.  You always think it's just one more go.  But, like binge-watching on Netflix, that rarely happens.
+Unique lightning attack actually messes with the gameplay in random ways.  This can save or kill you.  But you shall never know.  (I believe in RNGesus.)

Cringe-worthy Notes:
-Only two tracks. (Three if you unlock 'The Puginator') Not very memorable at that.  If you are just spending hours on this, you may wanna turn off the music and play your own.
-Touchy controls.  Sometimes, you can hit the jump button.  You know.  THE ONE BUTTON THAT DOES ANYTHING IN THE ENTIRE GAME?!  And you'll jump.  Other times, you'll fall, crash, drown, burn, etc.  C'mon, guys.  When you make a game like this, it's mandatory that the controls are tight.  Fix dat' sheet, por favor.
-Cats...I do not care for cats.  Why are cats in a dog game?! I'm allergic.

VERDICT:
This game is fun, but be prepared to have brain aneurysms of frustration when the clicking/spacebar spamming fail at critical moments.  A nice little time-waster for $0.99, but an even better one for $0.49.  

7.5/10 Would poop rainbows again

Oh, you need more? Well, for one it only costs a maximum of one total euro. 

It is basically the same game as, say, Robot Unicorn Attack, but then instead of the Blind Guardian song you've got a pug. It's also less expensive than Robot Unicorn Attack, if I remember correctly. And it seems to have slightly more diversity, too. The landscape changes as you go on, together with the weather and the background music.

You can unlock different pugs/cats/a Penguin(?) and each has its own specialty which might help you get farther into the level (which gets more difficult as you progress), adding a bit more to the variety of the game.

Although you might get bored of it pretty quickly, it's cute and cheap and if you've got a single euro to spare, this is worth it. But then again, I bought it because it has the word "pug" in it. It is the perfect game to play when you're supposed to be paying attention in class or at work, though.

[Actual pug snorting sounds not included]

20441574.review:
[u][h1]What The Pug Did I Just Waste My Money On[/h1] - [i]An Official Waffle King Review[/i][/u]
[u][i]~Find more [url=http://lordwaffleking.com/]here.[/url][/i][/u]

I'm a pretty attractive person. It's pretty nice, being attractive. I get to talk to the other attractive people, and I never feel like an unwanted burden to society. That can happen to the undesirables sometimes. The ones that are not as attractive.


But being as great as I am does indeed come with some drawbacks. Sometimes, I worry that I push people away. Being beautiful, intelligent, talented, and exceeding in all possible ways can put unwanted pressure on those beneath you. I worry sometimes that those around me might decide to just kill themselves when they realize nothing they can do will ever mean anything when compared to me.


I mean, hey, if I was in your shoes I totally would. If I was an undesirable like you, no doubt would I be staring down the barrel of a shotgun and hoping that I'd drunk enough to not feel a thing.


But that's not the answer, most of the time. The world needs all kinds of people. Beauty can be perceived in a lot of ways. Some people loves huskies, for their striking appearance. Some love pitbulls, for their innate power and presence. Some even love pugs, for their charmingly disfigured appearance.


See where I'm getting at? Just adopt a pug or something already and maybe people would like you more. If you adopt a puppy, you can't be THAT bad. And at least the puppy will never think less of you. They don't know any better.


If you're in the market for pugs though, just make sure you don't accidentally get this pug.


This is probably the worst pug you could get. Worse than the one with distemper that's wheezing in a puddle of its own vomit and diarrhea.


Turbo Pug is a pug-themed endless runner for the PC, available to download on Steam. At first glance, it definitely looks like Game of The Year material. But a darkness resides under its cheerful exterior. Like a distemper-ridden pug's steaming pile of mixed fluids and excrement on your loved one's bed that you covered up with a frilly throw pillow. They may not see it coming as they see it. They might smell something kind of off. But once you're in it, you're in it. And you'll wish you never had.


There's not much to Turbo Pug. It's an endless runner. Yeah, sure, short and simple games like that have a market. I'm not gonna knock it for being simplistic. That's kind of the genre. It's a really cheap game. Both cost and production value. It cost me pocket change. Like I'd bought lunch and threw whatever change they gave me into the trash accidentally. It really won't be missed. I'm not gonna go digging for my money back. It's just a little unfortunate. Gonna put a damper on the next 5 minutes of my life, until I forget about it and move on.


Runners can be decent. They can pass the time in a painless and easy way. Turbo Pug does not do that. Turbo Pug is a grind. An eyesore. I'd rather stare into the sun to pass the time than play this. And that would require me to put on pants and go outside. I'd rather put on pants than play this game. If I had a rating system, that would be the lowest of low ranks, below 0. "IGN says 0/10" "Kotaku says No" "Waffle King says Made Me Put On Pants". That's what this game gets.


Turbo Pug is the worst kind of endless runner. Bland, monotonous, and fails to hold your attention for longer than a minute. Reaction time between obstacles is short and brutal, meaning you're prone to dying awfully quick. Some obstacles even blend in with the surrounding background, and the screen scrolls so quick you'll often die before realizing what you hit. And it's always the same couple obstacles that'll kill you, because there's only so many in the game.


It's randomly generated, and yet only from playing it a handful of times I've already seen repeating areas. Like the game generates the level in chunks, and there aren't enough chunks to go around. Worse than life in gulag. Dark, cold. Chunks always spread too thin. Never enough for everyone. We starve.


You'll be sick of this game as soon as you boot it up. I'm not even kidding. Its stupid looping soundtrack, its stupidly simple gameplay, and its stupid art direction. You wouldn't believe how bad the art is, just from looking at screenshots. It might look good. Pixels are cute, pugs are cute. It's happy and bright, what's not to love?


It's nauseating to play. It hurts to stare at for longer than a minute. Trying to focus your eyes on the endlessly scrolling pixels as they race past you is headache-inducing. It's like no one play-tested this piece of shit. 


Or maybe they did, but they just swept the complaints under the rug, like pug diarrhea. "Oh, Little Billy got eye cancer from playing this game? They're all swollen up and leaking thick, musky fluids everywhere? One of his eyes exploded, you say, and splattered the other children with mushy eye residue? Quick, get the other children to stop playing. This game is ready to ship, and we don't want their precious eyes exploding. We can sell those on the black market. Now get them back in the warehouse, if this game flops we need brand-name knockoff shoes to sell." is probably exactly how that conversation went.


I like pugs. I really do. Pugs are nice. But you can't stick a pug on a stack of child corpses and call it art. It's illegal, and would get you banned from ever driving an ice cream truck ever again.


Some people are husky people, some people are pitbull people, some people are pug people. But just adopting a pug won't make you any less undesirable. You'd still be boring, unpleasant to look at for long periods of time, and stupid. Much like this game. Adding pugs doesn't fix all of your problems. It'll just get people to notice you, maybe throw some spare change your way, and entertain the thought of you for maybe a minute. But only just. After that it's just painful and awkward.

19467916.review:
I got this on sale for $0.49, not expecting much out of it. I mean, pugs are adorable, but there's only so much fun you can get out of a game where you just jump over obstacles and collect points.

Apparently I underestimated how much entertainment I would get out of this game, because - although I don't have very many hours logged yet - I've basically done it all in one sitting. It reminds me of the old-fashioned Mario games, actually, except you have the added bonus of adorable animal sprites and music that's really light-hearted and funky. 

What I really like, too, is that the sprites have different running styles, so even if you get really good at using the pug, for example, you have to relearn the timing of the jumps and whatnot for when you switch to using the cat. This means you can switch it up every once in a while without getting too bored.

I don't know how many hours of entertainment I'll get out of this, but it's a great game to play when I've got nothing to do and don't really have the capacity to play a game that requires much thought, like Skyrim. It's the perfect lazy day entertainment.

And like I said - I really, really like the music. Though I have to say, the sad animal sound effects when I die are kinda heart-wrenching sometimes.

My one negative comment would be that this really starts to hurt my eyes after a while because of the speed at which you're moving, and the screen tends to blur. I have really god-awful eyesight and sensitive eyes to go with it so this is probably a bigger issue for me than it is for other people, but it's something to keep in mind.

19244983.review:
I've never seen as many baseless and inane negative reviews for a genuinely good game as I have for Turbo Pug. While I firmly believe that everyone's entitled to their opinion, I can't accept the amount of distorted, hyperbolic nonsense that’s being perpetrated about this game and I find it hard to tolerate the people who have the gall to berate the game solely because of its shortcomings.

----------------------------------------

Turbo Pug is a damned good game. However, it definitely has its issues. Space Cat Studios tried new things in this title, some more ambitious than others, and not all of them were successful. 

It's true that dialogue has been watered down as the devs chose to forgo text conversation choices in favor of a voiced and much more simplified dialogue wheel, which is further hampered by boring choices and weak voice work. Character advancements have been combined into a single perk/SPECIAL sheet. Settlement building, while certainly fun, is mostly aesthetic filler that has little impact on the game world. Side quests far too often amount to just killing some mandatory enemies, particularly with the Pugs (who are supposed to be the "good guys" of this installment), and can become repetitive.

My most prominent grievance with Turbo Pug is the dialogue overhaul and removal of the biscuit system, which was completely unnecessary and not desired by a single player in existence. Unlike the previous flaws, this thoroughly irks me. I realized that this ties in to the primary weakness of Turbo Pug: its lack of meaningful dialogue in comparison to most Space cat Studios titles. Far too often, your dialogue choices are short, shallow, meaningless, or all three. 

The only choices that have any outcome are blatantly outlined as persuasion options, a lot of which only help you get some extra kibble. It's not that you should be making major decisions all the time; the problem is that you, as a speaking character, now have a voice that carries no power. What you decide to say is almost always inconsequential. The dialogue system is highly reminiscent of Bad Rats except watered down; the reason it doesn't work in Turbo Pug is that the two games have totally different approaches to conversation. The previous Space Cat Studio games had much better dialogue options because they meant something. Sometimes, your choice of words just made someone hate you, allowed you to entice or inspire others, or developed your reputation through the biscuit system. Now that biscuit is gone, your choices are just that much more pointless.

The bottom line is that Space Cat Studios sacrificed a tremendous amount of RPG dialogue elements to accommodate full voice-work. While it was an ambitious attempt, it was an all-around mistake and it sticks out like a sore if you're a fan of Space Cat Studios games or RPG's in general. The dialogue wheel system could have worked out just fine, but Space Cat Studios carried it out in the wrong way.

----------------------------------------

All the aforementioned flaws are some of the most central complaints naysayers have about Turbo Pug and yet not a single one of them has been horrific enough to ruin my experience or let me down. Despite the few bugs I've come across, despite the certain questionable and sometimes idiotic design choices Space Cat Studios made here, this game is still extremely well done. I still feel that incomparable thrill that only Turbo Pug can bring.

Even though Turbo Pug falls extremely short on dialogue and all aspects associated with it, it's still an improvement over its predecessors in almost every other way imaginable. The game suffers some graphical issues like muddy textures and poor lighting at times, like any good Space Cat Studios game, but it's still astoundingly beautiful and even breathtaking at times. Movement, melee, gunplay, and physics are better and smoother than they've ever been. 

People were quick to judge the Pugworld map based on its size and I was prepared to be disappointed as well, but it's surprisingly the best one Space Cat Studios has whipped up thus far. The suburban locations are more organically dispersed and things become more compressed as you near the cities. Streets are narrow, buildings are tall, and locations are absolutely jam-packed alongside a ton of unmarked ruins and buildings you can enter. There are hardly any copy-pasted environments and they all show great attention to detail.

I was also worried that granting access to Jowls and a Bone within the first thirty minutes of the game would be a huge balancing issue as well, but it really isn’t. The jowls rely on uncommon fusion slobber goobs for power and you’re not an unstoppable god while weilding the jowls, especially not at higher difficulties or levels. You can acquire some strong weapons like the Bad or Rat relatively early but finding sufficient ammo is another matter entirely.

----------------------------------------

Gta V was a simplification of the Bad Rats formula, but it was still a fantastic game. In much the same way, Turbo Pug is a simplification of the Call of Duty:Ghosts formula and is still extremely good. Even in light of its issues, this game has not been a disappointment at all. RPG elements can be enhanced through the wonderful modding community and will eventually make up for some of the game's weaker points, a perk of being a PC gamer. Space Cat Studios has, however, been on a recent trend of simplifying their games too much and I hope they change course.

Truthfully, the negative Steam reviews had me partly worried that I’d be disappointed but I chose to disregard them and arrive at my own opinion. I’ve learned that nearly every point of contention was blown out of context. The few issues that haven’t been redeemed in my eyes still pale in the face of the tremendous work that was done to bring this new and beautiful Turbo Pug world to life. I have no doubt that the naysayers worked up their expectations to heights beyond reason, and it’s therefore no mystery that they hit the ground so hard afterwards. I chose to see Turbo Pug for what it is rather than what I expected or imagined it to be: a lovingly crafted game that, despite being marred by some of its shortcomings, has that same engaging splendor that far supercedes its flaws.

I highly recommend you try the game and approach it with a neutral and reasonable demeanor, and you won’t be disappointed.

Alright, for an honest review of this game... It's very basic. There's very little depth to it. Just your basic endless runner, without any powerups and with a relatively small selection of randomized obstacles.

It does have fairly nice pixelated graphics, although sometimes it's difficult to see certain obstacles when it's raining. The music is fantastic too, although there's only two songs.

The only variation while playing is the different pugs (and cats) that you can choose from, which do alter the gameplay slightly, but not enough to give the game actual depth.

One last little note, there's lightning strikes that you can't avoid that, while not immediately killing you, stun your pug for a moment and usually cause it to fall into spikes or run into a wall. Which will inevitably cause the best players to eventually die not from a lack of skill, but unavoidable crap.

'big black cock rammed inside of a dead baby', no, this isnt just a random statement, this is actually written in the game...

Theres one control in this game and that is to Jump which is expectedly done using the Space Bar, the game is one of them casual (hardcore) kind of simple games that are on rails and you just press a button within good timing to triumph, similar to The Impossible Game, Geometry Dash, Super Hexagon amd oO

The 'controls' section when you start up the game is a lie as there is only actually one control and that is to Jump. There are other controls listed such as 'fire' but none of them actually exist in-game as pressing the said button for such functions dont actually have such or even any result, theres also an option to use a Controller but the controller doesnt actually work in the game

The 'leaderboards' feature is also a lie as not only is the entire leaderboard just full of '9r' scores but they arent actually online scores, its just a made up leaderboard within the game

The 'procedurally generated levels' feature is a lie too as they arent procedurally generated but rather its just several different levels that get chosen at random

the game also has a 'graphics' setting which is a lie too (not to mention wtf would you need a graphics setting on a game like this anyways), changing the graphics setting does absolutely nothing and the game was made on GM8 so ofcourse you cant change the graphics settings...

It would be nice if when you held the Jump button, that you actually continued jumping every time you landed back down but as it is; you have to keep pressing the Jump button after every time you land

Theres 6 'pugs' to choose from (2 of which look like cats but hey, they must be Pugs because the game says 'choose your pug') but they arent just cosmetic changes, and are unbalanced as its just the further you go down the list of Pugs, the more times that you can do an airbourne jump, so clearly, the one at the end of the list of pugs to choose from is the best. Oh, and why is there a gay pug?

Theres only 2 songs and both are mindnumbing and don't suite the pace of the game, they also both start when your Pug dies instead of when you start the session, so you end up starting to play when the song is part way through

Wow. With a deep, complex story line, amazing characters with rich backstorys, Turbo Pug is a game that only comes around once in a blue moon. This is easily the most fantastic game of 2015, and it very well may be that way for years to come. Forget Fallout 4, screw Black Ops 3. They dont have a single thing on Turbo Pug. 

The beautiful textures, and scenic rolling hills are by far the best I have ever seen in any game. The devs really did it with the fantastic use of Nvidia's hairworks, this feature is overwealmingly important in a game with these adorable furry pugs. Watching their hair blow in the wind as you navigate through the stage is quite satisfying. 

The levels have been expertly crafted for the absolute best playing experience, platform to platform, box to box. It truly feels like you are there, freerunning across the vast open landscape and collecting those ever important Pug Coins.

I truly experienced this game and I have little more to say about it, yet I know I have barly scratched the surface on what it has to offer. 11/10 - IGN

19023893.review:
Over the years I’ve played a dozen iterations of screenscrolling games and their predecessors. I’ve played twenty odd games from Mario Brothers to Super Smash Brothers. I've gotten quite good at them, too. I’ve won the World Cup, the Champions League, the Premiership, the Championship, League One, Serie A, La Liga, the Bundesliga, and most importantly, the Romanian Second Division. By this point in the last game I played, I thought I was done. An assortment of minor annoyances and disappointments with Luigi's Mansion left me too frustrated to continue.

It didn’t last. This year's edition, while flawed, has fixed just enough of my quibbles to draw me back in. And as ever, Turbo Pug remains a fairytale generator. It’s perfectly possible to arrive at a struggling landscape with a grand history, implement innovative new tactics, and take your pug back to the top. It's just easy enough that you can do it, but just hard enough that you’re never quite certain you can. It’s balanced on a beautiful knife edge, and its greatest achievement is selling you the fantasy of sitting in the pug owner's chair.
The pugs on display this year are distinctly modern too, with a degree of fluidity and position swapping that feels authentic to today’s dog world. The fact that striker-less tactics (something real world pug owners have been dabbling with for years) have now finally found their way into the game’s preset formations shows a willingness to keep up with the times. If Luigi's Mansion felt oddly retro, Turbo Pug is cutting-edge.

That’s not to say that all my problems with Turbo Pug have gone away. I still think the game has a serious problem with bloat. People play Turbo Pug for a lot of reasons, and I’ve been aggressively reminded in the past that those who desire a "realistic" simulation actively enjoy the incredibly slow scouting and endless questions from the media. It’s not a position I can agree with, though. I find these time-sinks an irritating barrier to playing the runs, and as a result, Turbo Pug and I have been drifting apart for a while.

Thankfully, three years ago its creators at Space Cat Studios acknowledged this split in the fanbase by introducing Classic Mode, which has now been confusingly rebranded to Turbo Pug 2: Simple Edition, even though it plays just fine with a mouse and keyboard. It offers a stripped-down, fluid approach to play. It was a godsend, offering a version of the game that focused on what I felt was important.

The user interface, which in older iterations looked little better than colored spreadsheets, has become slick and intuitive.
Turbo Pug typically comes with an army of borderline-inconsequential tweaks that together deliver a noticeable difference overall but individually are difficult to rave about. There are, however, several new features here that had a meaningful impact. Let's start with the new multi-pug feature, which is a perfect example of the series’ penchant for incremental improvement working well. For years now I’ve been mildly irritated by the fact that I can only have one pug, regardless of whether I wanted to have more than one pug. Now, with the click of a couple buttons, this problem is solved, and I can have many pugs to frolic the fields with.

Then there’s Create a Pug mode. As far back as I can remember, Turbo Pug fans have used game editors to add their unique pugs to the game. There’s a whole culture of forums full of different pug designs like these. Now Space Cat Studios has acknowledged this strange social aspect of the game, and offers players the chance to create a pug in a far more accessible way.

I’m also strangely entranced by the option to create an on pitch avatar for your pug, letting him yell and scream at his pug friends from the sidelines. They all look absolutely terrible, but there’s something strangely endearing about them too. For the record, yes, you can select either male or female pugs.
Yet at the same time, I have to acknowledge that the "full" mode of Turbo Pug is still very much not for me. Many of this year’s new features involve expanded media interactions, a part of the game that hasn’t worked well for a long time. I still get dog lovers interrupting me to voice their concerns that we don’t have enough dog treats, despite the fact that I’m not planning on feeding my pugs. I’m told I can dismiss their concerns assertively, cautiously, calmly, or passionately; unfortunately, I’m not really sure what the difference is.

Interestingly, Space Cat Studios has said it plans to sell a standalone version of Turbo Pug 2: Simple Edition, with a release date of "sometime before Christmas." If you’re the same kind of Turbo Pug player as me, you may be better off waiting for that. For now, you can find Turbo Pug 2: Simple Edition here in Steam. Many of the new features--the Pug Creator, Create a Dog Treat and a lightly tweaked tactics UI--are available in Simple Edition while almost everything I dislike has been cut. This, coupled with the fact that the match engine feels just a little bit more German Shepherd than Jack Russel this year, was enough to draw me back in.

Shoutouts: Sean, mom, papa john
